data.text: The faculty of making fortunate discoveries by accident.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The fact or occurrence of such discoveries.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An instance of making such a discovery.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The happy faculty, or luck, of finding, by “accidental sagacity,” interesting items of information or unexpected proofs of one's theories; discovery of things unsought: a factitious word humorously invented by Horace Walpole.
An unsought, unintended, and/or unexpected discovery and/or learning experience that happens by accident and <xref>sagacity</xref>.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: A combination of events which are not individually beneficial, but occurring together produce a good or wonderful outcome.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: good luck in making unexpected and fortunate discoveries
data.attributionText: from WordNet 3.0 Copyright 2006 by Princeton University. All rights reserved.
